author: @mockapp6973
text: A friend of mine turned down his first medical school that offered to pay half his tuition for 4 years. We he wrote them declining the offer for another school. They then countered that initial offer with a  full ride scholarship. He still turned them down, even though the 2nd school was offering a 1/2 ride scholarship for all 4 years. He may have stayed with the 1st school had they initially offered him a full ride. The only motivation that I see that people(recruiters or managers) get from these offer games has to be financial on their part. Anyway, Congrats on the new job and on posting a very insightful video.

author: @ldsudduthhanover
text: 8:12  "I'm Loyal."  BOOM--- a trait missing from so many today.  IF your employer treats you well, you're compensated fairly, and the perks are good, then your employer should always be given the opportunity to negotiate to keep you. There is something in the argument that yes, they should have already been doing more--but communication is a two-way street. If you're searching for more opportunity and would like to pursue it within the company you work for, let your management team know you're willing to take on additional responsibilities. They may be thinking of doing something and looking outside for a candidate because they don't know someone on the team already is interested.

author: @aidanoconnor594
text: Hi Alex. I want to start by saying it's great to see you are feeling better and I wish you nothing but the best of luck in your new role. You are doing everybody looking to get into this industry a great service and you deserve any and all success that comes your way.  I also want to focus on what you said about PwC and how they wanted you to shut down your channel due to a "conflict of interest". This is interesting (and a bit unsettling) because this has happened to at least one other prominent Youtuber called "Techlead". He was fired from Facebook with the reason cited being that his channel was a "conflict of interest".  At the risk of sounding naive, stupid, or uninformed... can you explain why your channel would be a conflict of interest? Is it because:  A) They are worried that you will directly or indirectly "advertise" for competitors or leak sensitive information?  B) You giving tutorials and giving tips on the data analyst hiring process will cause a greater influx of uniform-and-impressive-looking job applications and will put greater pressure on HR.  C) The opposite of B): your videos will encourage people to try for higher prestige companies like Google or Abbots, thereby decreasing the number of prospective applicants.  D) Some other factors I never thought of.  I apologize for this long comment AND for asking a question whose answer could possibly taint your professional persona. It's just what you said about the interview with PwC kind of alarmed me. I have just finished reading 1984 by George Orwell, so I guess I'm a little paranoid :-D.  Keep up the good work!

However, I am definitely of the mindset you mentioned which is, if they really valued you, they'd have been paying you that salary already. Companies will not hesitate to replace workers if its beneficial to them. Loyalty to your co-workers and friends is great, but loyalty to the job/position/company can definitely kneecap you. Congratulations on your new role!
